cluster_relations.rel_desc: The caterpillar forms the chrysalis, a protective shell around itself.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when it stops eating and prepares for the next stage

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Butterfly wings are formed as new tissues during metamorphosis.
Antennae are among the new structures that form during metamorphosis.
The chrysalis is the structure from which the adult butterfly (adult stage) emerges.
remarks: Adult stage is represented via the adult butterfly stage entity.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The organism (caterpillar) constructs or forms a chrysalis structure around itself as part of metamorphosis.
args.justification: This relation specifically represents the caterpillar creating its chrysalis as a distinct developmental act; a specific predicate makes the lifecycle transition explicit.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A developmental process (such as metamorphosis) produces or develops a new anatomical structure (e.g., wings, antennae).
args.justification: Both relations describe the same semantic pattern: the metamorphosis process developing specific body structures inside the chrysalis; they should share a unified predicate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A life-cycle structure or stage gives rise to or transitions into the subsequent life-cycle stage (e.g., chrysalis to adult butterfly stage).
args.justification: The relation encodes a specific life-cycle transition where the chrysalis is the origin from which the adult stage emerges; a stage-transition predicate is appropriate.
The caterpillar forming a chrysalis is a concrete instance of forming a new protective structure as part of development.
Both relations involve a developmental process (metamorphosis) generating anatomical structures, which fits a morphogenesis-focused relation class.
The chrysalis giving rise to the adult butterfly stage is a canonical example of a life-cycle stage transition.
The caterpillar is the causal agent that forms the chrysalis; the relation denotes creation/formation as a causal act.
Metamorphosis is the causal developmental process that brings wings and antennae into existence, fitting a causal formation category.
This relation expresses an ordered life-cycle progression from chrysalis to adult stage, fundamentally temporal in nature.
